facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1326 of 1973 was filed before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1326 of 1973.

facts.text: Himachal Pradesh High Court delivered Judgment/Order dated 31st July 1973 in Election Petition No. 10 of 1972.

anchor.surface_text: From the Judgment Order datey the 31st July, 1973 of the Himachal Pradesh High Court in Election Petition No. 10 of 1972.

facts.text: Elections were held in March 1972 to the Himachal Pradesh State Legislative Assembly.

anchor.surface_text: Elections were held in March 1972 to the Himachal Pradesh State Legislative Assembly.

facts.text: The 1st respondent was elected to the Himachal Pradesh State Legislative Assembly from the Shahpur Constituency in Kangra District.

anchor.surface_text: The 1st respondent was elected to that Assembly from the Shahpur Constituency in Kangra District.

facts.text: Appellant filed an election petition as a voter in Shahpur Constituency.

anchor.surface_text: An election petition was filed by the appellant, a voter in that constituency,

facts.text: Election petition claimed 1st respondent held office of profit under Government of Himachal Pradesh at time of filing nominations, disqualifying under Article 191(1)(a).

anchor.surface_text: on the ground, among others, that at the time of filing of nominations the 1st respondent was holding an office of profit under the Government of Himachal Pradesh and as such was disqualified for election under Article 191  1   a  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Himachal Pradesh High Court dismissed the election petition.

anchor.surface_text: The petition having been dismissed by the High Court of Himachal Pradesh this appeal has been filed against the order of dismissal.

facts.text: 1st respondent was nominated as Chairman of the Board of School Education of Himachal Pradesh in 1969 by Himachal Pradesh Government under Himachal Pradesh Board of School Education Act, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The 1st respondent was nominated Chairman of the Board of School Education of Himachal Pradesh in the year 1969 by the Himachal Pradesh Government under the provisions of the Himachal Pradesh Board of School Education Act, 1968.

facts.text: 1st respondent was holding the post of Chairman at all relevant times.

anchor.surface_text: At all relevant times he was holding that post.

facts.text: Chairman is nominated by the Government under section 18 of the Himachal Pradesh Board of School Education Act, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 18 of the Act the Chairman is nominated by the Government.

facts.text: Board is constituted by the Government under section 3 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Board is constituted by the Government under S. 3 of the Act.

facts.text: Office of Chairman of the Board is an office under the State Government.

anchor.surface_text: There can be very little dispute and indeed it is not disputed that the office of the Chairman of the Board is an office under the State Government.

facts.text: 1st respondent was not in receipt of a salary.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, the 1st respondent was not in receipt of a salary.

facts.text: 1st respondent appointed as Chairman in honorary capacity.

anchor.surface_text: The order appointing him to the post of Chairman makes it clear that he was appointed only in an honorary capacity.

facts.text: 1st respondent entitled to travelling and daily allowance, not a disqualification under section 3(m) of Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly Members Removal of Disqualifications Act, 1971.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that he was entitled to receive travelling and daily allowance in the course of the discharge of his duties as Chairman would not be a disqualification because of the provisions of section 3  m  of the Himachal Pradesh Legislative Assembly Members  Removal of Disqualifications  Act, 1971, and this is not disputed.

facts.text: Petitioner contends that the post carried a scale of pay.

anchor.surface_text: What is, however, contended on behalf of the appellant is that though the 1st respondent might not have been in receipt of a salary, the post itself carried a scale of pay and therefore it is an office of profit which the 1st respondent was holding.

facts.text: Board passed Resolution No. 12 on January 17, 1970 fixing salary of Rs. 1600-1800 per month for Chairman.

anchor.surface_text: This contention that the post carried a scale of pay is based on Resolution No. 12 passed by the Board on January 17, 1970 fixing a salary of Rs. 16001800 per month for the Chairman.

facts.text: Court held that Board was not competent to fix scale of pay for Chairman by resolution.

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the Board was not competent to fix a scale of pay for the Chairman by a resolution.

facts.text: No regulations made fixing scale of pay for Chairman.

anchor.surface_text: The first Regulations were made by the Government under section 27 and in the Regulations so made there is no provision for the scale of pay of the Chairman of the Board. Nor have we been shown any regulation made by the Board fixing the scale of pay of the Chairman.

facts.text: Supreme Court held 1st respondent not holding office of profit at time of nomination or election.

anchor.surface_text: We held, therefore, in agreement with the High Court that the 1st respondent was not holding an office of profit at the time when he filed his nomination or when he was elected.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal is, therefore, dismissed with costs.

facts.text: Government presumed competent to remove Chairman.

anchor.surface_text: Though there is nothing said in the Act about the authority competent to remove the Chairman from his office it may be assumed for the purposes of this case that the Government was competent to do so.

facts.text: Secretary to the Board appointed by Government under section 22.

anchor.surface_text: The Secretary to the Board is also appointed by the Government upon such conditions and for such period as the Government may deem fit under section 22.

facts.text: Petitioner contended section 10 clause 18 enables Board to fix scale of pay of Chairman.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the contention on behalf of the appellant that section 10, clause  18  of the Himachal pradesh Board of School Education Act, 1968 enables the Board to fix the scale of pay of the Chairman.
under Article 191  1   a  of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether at the time of filing of nominations the 1st respondent was holding an office of profit under the Government of Himachal Pradesh and as such was disqualified for election under Article 191(1)(a) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: an election petition was filed by the appellant, a voter in that constituency, on the ground, among others, that at the time of filing of nominations the 1st respondent was holding an office of profit under the Government of Himachal Pradesh and as such was disqualified for election under Article 191  1   a  of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the Ist respondent was holding an office of profit under the State Government and was disqualified under Article 191(1)(a) of the Constitution to be elected as a member of the State Legislative Assembly

anchor.surface_text: The only ground which is relevant for the purpose of decision of this appeal and which was urged before this Court, was that as the Ist respondent was holding an office of profit under the State Government lie was disqualified under Article 191  1   a  of the Constitution to be elected as a member of the State Legislative Assembly.

issues.text: whether it is an office of profit

anchor.surface_text: whether it is an office of profit.

issues.text: whether the holding of the office has resulted in any profit to the holder of that office, however small that profit may be

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether the holding of the office has resulted in any profit to the holder of that office, however small that profit may be.

issues.text: whether the post itself carried a scale of pay and therefore it is an office of profit

anchor.surface_text: What is, however, contended on behalf of the appellant is that though the 1st respondent might not have been in receipt of a salary, the post itself carried a scale of pay and therefore it is an office of profit which the 1st respondent was holding.

issues.text: whether the Board was competent to fix a scale of pay for the Chairman by a resolution

anchor.surface_text: This contention that the-post carried a scale of pay is based on Resolution No. 12 passed by the Board on January 17, 1970 fixing a salary of Rs. 16001800 per month for the Chairman. We are satisfied that the Board was not competent to fix a scale of pay for the Chairman by a resolution.

issues.text: whether section 10, clause 18 of the Himachal Pradesh Board of School Education Act, 1968 enables the Board to fix the scale of pay of the Chairman

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the contention on behalf of the appellant that section 10, clause  18  of the Himachal pradesh Board of School Education Act, 1968 enables the Board to fix the scale of pay of the Chairman. The fixing of the scale of pay of the Chairman cannot be said to be an act ancillary to any of the purposes mentioned in cls. 1 to 17 of the section or to be one for the purpose or carrying into effect the provisions of the Act.

issues.text: whether he can sue for or otherwise claim the scale of pay fixed by the resolution of the Board

anchor.surface_text: In any case as far as the 1st respondent is concerned the test for deciding whether he holds an office of profit is very simple. It is whether he can sue for or otherwise claim the scale of pay fixed by the resolution of the Board.

arguments.court_reasoning: Board not competent to fix scale of pay by resolution

arguments.claim: Section 10 clause 18 enables Board to fix scale of pay for Chairman

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the contention on behalf of the appellant that section 10, clause  18  of the Himachal pradesh Board of School Education Act, 1968 enables the Board to fix the scale of pay of the Chairman.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: s the Government may deem fit, which as in the case of the, Secretary would include the power to fix their scale of pay. This is clear from the fact t

arguments.court_reasoning: Fixing pay not ancillary to purposes in cls 1-17 or for carrying out Act

arguments.claim: Office of profit requires actual profit accruing to holder, however small

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether the holding of the office has resulted in any profit to the holder of that office, however small that profit may be.

arguments.claim: No profit accruing to 1st respondent, hence not office of profit

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of any profit accruing to the 1st respondent as a result of the holding of the office of Chairman it cannot be said that he was holding an office, of profit.

arguments.claim: Appointment was honorary; not even case of salary provided but waived

anchor.surface_text: This is number even a case where the Chairman was appointed to an office and a salary was provided for him by the order of appoint- ment Or he was entitled to a salary as a result of the appointment a he gave up his right to the salary. The order of appointment itself was one made in an honorary capacity.

arguments.claim: Board incompetent to fix Chairman's pay by resolution

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the Board was not competent to fix a scale of pay for the Chairman by a resolution.

arguments.claim: Section 10(18) does not empower Board to fix Chairman's pay; not ancillary to cls 1-17 or for Act

anchor.surface_text: The fixing of the scale of pay of the Chairman cannot be said to be an act ancillary to any of the purposes mentioned in cls. 1 to 17 of the section or to be one for the purpose or carrying into effect the provisions of the Act.

arguments.claim: Section 23(4) does not enable Board to fix Chairman's pay; excludes high officers, Chairman distinct

anchor.surface_text: This sub-section when it enables the Board to make regulations regarding qualifications, companyditions of service and scales of pay of officers and servants of the Board other than the Deputy Secretary and Assistant Secretary, applies only to the cases of officers lower in rank than These officers mentioned. The Dresence of the word officer in that sub-section cannot be held to refer to the Chairman also merely because he is also called an officer of the Board under section 17.

arguments.claim: Curious if Act left Chairman's pay to Board while Govt fixes for Secretary etc.

anchor.surface_text: It would be curious if the Act while companyferring on the Government the power to specify the companyditions of service including the scales of pay of Deputy Secretary, Assistant Secretary and Secretary, it had left to the Board to determine the scale of pay of the Chairman by clubbing him 7-L319SupCI/75 along with officers and servants of the Board lower in rank than even the Assistant Secretary.

arguments.claim: No regulations by Govt or Board fix Chairman's scale of pay

anchor.surface_text: The first Regulations were made by the Government under section 27 and in the Regulations so made there is no provision for the scale of pay of the Chairman of the Board. Nor have we been shown any regulation made by the Board fixing the scale of pay of the Chairman.

arguments.claim: Section 26(2)(i) does not cover Chairman's appointment or conditions

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that section 26 2   i , which relates to the power of the Board to make Regulations for the appointment of officers, clerks and other servants of the Board and the companyditions of their service can companyer the Chairman because there is numberquestion of the Board being companypetent to deal with the appointment or companyditions of service of the Chairman.

arguments.claim: Section 26(2)(p) refers to emoluments of members, not Chairman; s.4 distinguishes Chairman from members

anchor.surface_text: Clause  p  of sub-s.  2  of section 26 speaks of the emoluments and allowances of the members of the Board and all its Committees. This clause when it refers to members of the Board cannot refer to the Chairman. The distinction between the Chairman and the members is brought out in section 4 which says that the Board shall companysist of the Chairman numberinated in accordance with section 18 and of the following members

arguments.claim: Act has no provision enabling Board to fix Chairman's pay by resolution

anchor.surface_text: On a close reading of the provisions of the Act we are satisfied that there is numberprovision in the Act enabling the Board to fix a scale of pay for the Chairman by a resolution. Therefore, it cannot be said that the resolution has validly fixed a scale of pay for the Chairman and, therefore, it cannot be said that the post of the Chairman carries with it a scale of pay.

arguments.claim: Test for 1st respondent: whether he can sue for or claim scale of pay fixed by Board resolution

anchor.surface_text: In any case as far as the 1st respondent is concerned the test for deciding whether he holds an office of profit is very simple. It is whether he can sue for or otherwise claim the scale of pay fixed by the resolution of the Board.

arguments.claim: 1st respondent cannot claim salary given honorary appointment order

anchor.surface_text: In the face of his order of appointment such a claim would number be upheld.

arguments.claim: 1st respondent not holding office of profit at nomination or election

anchor.surface_text: We held, therefore, in agreement with the High Court that the Ist respondent was number holding an office of profit at the time when he filed his numberination or when he was elected.

holdings.text: the 1st respondent was not holding an office of profit at the time when he filed his nomination or when he was elected

anchor.surface_text: We held, therefore, in agreement with the High Court that the 1st respondent was not holding an office of profit at the time when he filed his nomination or when he was elected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Honorary appointment with no salary paid, no valid scale of pay fixed by Board lacking competence, no profit accrued to holder, cannot claim salary against appointment order

holdings.text: In the absence of any profit accruing to the 1st respondent as a result of the holding of the office of Chairman it cannot be said that he was holding an office of profit

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of any profit accruing to the 1st respondent as a result of the holding of the office of Chairman it cannot be said that he was holding an office, of profit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied test from prior judgment that office of profit requires actual profit to holder however small; no salary received and appointment honorary

holdings.text: the Board was not competent to fix a scale of pay for the Chairman by a resolution

anchor.surface_text: We are satisfied that the Board was not competent to fix a scale of pay for the Chairman by a resolution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No enabling provision in Act for resolution to fix pay; Chairman's pay not covered by Board's regulatory powers over lower officers

holdings.text: section 10, clause 18 of the Himachal Pradesh Board of School Education Act, 1968 does not enable the Board to fix the scale of pay of the Chairman

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the contention on behalf of the appellant that section 10, clause 18 of the Himachal pradesh Board of School Education Act, 1968 enables the Board to fix the scale of pay of the Chairman. The fixing of the scale of pay of the Chairman cannot be said to be an act ancillary to any of the purposes mentioned in cls. 1 to 17 of the section or to be one for the purpose or carrying into effect the provisions of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fixing Chairman's pay not ancillary to purposes in clauses 1-17 nor for carrying out Act provisions

holdings.text: section 23(4) does not enable the Board to determine the scale of pay of the Chairman

anchor.surface_text: We are clearly of opinion that section 23 4 does not enable the Board to determine the scale of pay of the Chairman.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Subsection applies only to lower officers and servants excluding high officers like Secretary etc.; Chairman distinct and higher; purposive reading avoids absurdity

holdings.text: there is no provision in the Act enabling the Board to fix a scale of pay for the Chairman by a resolution

anchor.surface_text: On a close reading of the provisions of the Act we are satisfied that there is no provision in the Act enabling the Board to fix a scale of pay for the Chairman by a resolution. Therefore, it cannot be said that the resolution has validly fixed a scale of pay for the Chairman and, therefore, it cannot be said that the post of the Chairman carries with it a scale of pay.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Comprehensive review of ss.10(18),23(4),26(2)(i),(p),27,4,17,19 shows no power over Chairman's pay which is governmental function

holdings.text: section 26(2)(i) does not cover the Chairman

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that section 26 2 i , which relates to the power of the Board to make Regulations for the appointment of officers, clerks and other servants of the Board and the conditions of their service can cover the Chairman because there is no question of the Board being competent to deal with the appointment or conditions of service of the Chairman.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Board lacks competence over Chairman's appointment or service conditions as nominated/removed by Government

holdings.text: Clause p of sub-s. 2 of section 26 refers to emoluments of members not Chairman

anchor.surface_text: Clause p of sub-s. 2 of section 26 speaks of the emoluments and allowances of the members of the Board and all its Committees. This clause when it refers to members of the Board cannot refer to the Chairman. The distinction between the Chairman and the members is brought out in section 4 which says that the Board shall consist of the Chairman nominated in accordance with section 18 and of the following members

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.4 distinguishes Chairman from members; clause p on members' emoluments/allowances, Act contemplates no scale of pay for members

holdings.text: the test for deciding whether he holds an office of profit is whether he can sue for or otherwise claim the scale of pay fixed by the resolution of the Board

anchor.surface_text: In any case as far as the 1st respondent is concerned the test for deciding whether he holds an office of profit is very simple. It is whether he can sue for or otherwise claim the scale of pay fixed by the resolution of the Board.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied to facts: honorary appointment order precludes any claim to salary

holdings.text: the Government was competent to remove the Chairman from his office

anchor.surface_text: Though there is nothing said in the Act about the authority competent to remove the Chairman from his office it may be assumed for the purposes of this case that the Government was competent to do so.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumed arguendo as nothing in Act specifies but not disputed and logical given nomination power

precedents.cited_proposition: whether the holding of the office has resulted in any profit to the holder of that office, however small that profit may be

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept the contention on behalf of the appellant that section 10, clause 18 of the Himachal pradesh Board of School Education Act, 1968 enables the Board to fix the scale of pay of the Chairman. The fixing of the scale of pay of the Chairman cannot be said to be an act ancillary to any of the purposes mentioned in cls. 1 to 17 of the section or to be one for the purpose or carrying into effect the provisions of the Act.

We held, therefore, in agreement with the High Court that the Ist respondent was number holding an office of profit at the time when he filed his numberination or when he was elected. The appeal is, therefore, dismissed with companyts.

edges.explanation: Holding h6 states no provision enabling the Board to fix pay scale by resolution, addressing the competence issue i6.

anchor.surface_text: On a close reading of the provisions of the Act we are satisfied that there is no provision in the Act enabling the Board to fix a scale of pay for the Chairman by a resolution. Therefore, it cannot be said that the resolution has validly fixed a scale of pay for the Chairman and, therefore, it cannot be said that the post of the Chairman carries with it a scale of pay.

We held, therefore, in agreement with the High Court that the Ist respondent was number holding an office of profit at the time when he filed his numberination or when he was elected. The appeal is, therefore, dismissed with companyts.

anchor.surface_text: In any case as far as the 1st respondent is concerned the test for deciding whether he holds an office of profit is very simple. It is whether he can sue for or otherwise claim the scale of pay fixed by the resolution of the Board.

We held, therefore, in agreement with the High Court that the Ist respondent was number holding an office of profit at the time when he filed his numberination or when he was elected. The appeal is, therefore, dismissed with companyts.
